text: The right hand of the LORD is exalted: the right hand of the LORD doeth valiantly.
text_kjv: The right hand of the LORD is exalted: the right hand of the LORD doeth valiantly.
text_niv: The Lord’s right hand is lifted high;the Lord’s right hand has done mighty things!”
text_esv: the right hand of the LORD exalts, the right hand of the LORD does valiantly!”
text_nlt: The strong right arm of the LORD is raised in triumph.The strong right arm of the LORD has done glorious things!
text_msg: The hand of God is raised in victory!The hand of God has turned the tide!"
text_nasb: The right hand of the LORD is exalted; The right hand of the LORD does valiantly.
context: Psalm 118 is a hymn of thanksgiving, likely sung during a festival procession or celebration commemorating a significant victory or deliverance. It's often associated with Passover or the Feast of Tabernacles. The psalm celebrates God's enduring lovingkindness (Hesed) and his power to rescue his people from their enemies. The phrase "His lovingkindness endures forever" is a recurring refrain, emphasizing the steadfastness of God's covenantal relationship with Israel. The use of the "right hand" is deeply rooted in ancient Near Eastern culture. The right hand symbolized strength, authority, skill, and honor. Warriors held their weapons in their right hand, making it the hand of power in battle. Kings often sat at the right hand of another ruler as a sign of honor and authority. In the context of the psalm, invoking the 'right hand' of the LORD invokes the image of a divine warrior, actively intervening on behalf of Israel. This psalm may have been used as part of the Hallel Psalms (Psalms 113-118) recited during Jewish festivals, particularly Passover, given its themes of deliverance and thanksgiving. Its liturgical function involved call-and-response elements, where the priests or Levites would sing certain verses, and the congregation would respond with phrases like, "His lovingkindness endures forever."
meaning: Psalm 118:16 emphasizes two related but distinct aspects of God's power. First, "The right hand of the LORD is exalted" signifies that God's strength and authority are unmatched and lifted high above all others. It speaks to his supreme sovereignty and his unchallengeable position in the cosmos. 'Exalted' suggests not just inherent power, but also the public recognition and acknowledgement of that power. God’s power is not hidden or latent; it is evident and glorified. Second, "the right hand of the LORD doeth valiantly" describes the active exercise of God's power. 'Doeth valiantly' suggests courageous, effective, and victorious action. It’s not merely possessing power but using it to overcome obstacles, defend the weak, and achieve triumph. This active demonstration of God's might reassures believers that God is not a passive observer but an active participant in their lives and in the world. The repetition of "the right hand of the LORD" reinforces the central theme of God's omnipotence and efficacy. Theologically, this verse points to the nature of God as both powerful and benevolent. His power is not arbitrary or capricious; it is wielded in accordance with his lovingkindness and justice. He uses his power to uphold his promises and to protect those who trust in him. This passage also foreshadows the messianic role of Jesus Christ. In the New Testament, Jesus is often depicted as sitting at the right hand of God the Father, signifying his authority and power. The valiant acts of Jesus, particularly his atoning death and resurrection, embody the fulfillment of this verse. His victory over sin and death demonstrates the ultimate triumph of God's right hand.
application: In modern life, Psalm 118:16 serves as a powerful reminder of God's active presence and unwavering power in our lives. When facing challenges, whether personal, relational, or societal, this verse encourages us to remember that God is not distant or indifferent but actively involved and capable of intervening. Recalling the verse allows us to cultivate a mindset of faith and trust, even when circumstances seem bleak. We can actively choose to acknowledge and celebrate God's power in our lives, not just in moments of great triumph, but also in the everyday struggles and uncertainties. Practically, this can involve incorporating this verse into our prayer life, meditating on its meaning, and sharing it with others who need encouragement. It also calls us to consider how we use our own 'right hands' – our own skills, abilities, and resources – to do valiantly in the world. Are we using our power to uplift others, to stand for justice, and to promote God's kingdom? Furthermore, recognizing God's exalted right hand should shape our perspective on earthly power. While worldly authorities may seem imposing, they are ultimately subordinate to God's supreme authority. This understanding can help us navigate complex ethical dilemmas and resist the temptation to compromise our values in pursuit of worldly success or approval. We can draw strength from the knowledge that God's power transcends all earthly limitations. Living out this verse means actively seeking opportunities to witness and participate in God's valiant acts in the world. This may involve supporting organizations that are working to alleviate suffering, advocating for policies that promote justice, or simply offering a helping hand to someone in need. By aligning our actions with God's purposes, we become instruments of his power and partners in his work of redemption.
prayer: Lord, your right hand is exalted, a beacon of strength and unwavering power. I acknowledge your supreme authority and your active presence in my life. Forgive me for the times I have doubted your ability to intervene in my circumstances. Help me to trust in your valiant acts, knowing that you are working for my good and for your glory. Empower me to use my own abilities and resources to do valiantly in the world, to stand for justice, and to show compassion to those in need. May your power be manifest in my life, that others may see your greatness and give you praise. Fill me with courage and faith, so that I may face every challenge with the assurance of your unwavering presence. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: 'Hesed,' meaning steadfast love or lovingkindness, is a crucial theme in Psalm 118. God's 'Hesed' motivates His valiant acts. His power isn't arbitrary, but an expression of His covenantal love, ensuring the welfare of His people. His right hand acts because of His Hesed.
faqs.question: Q1: How does 'Hesed' relate to Psalm 118:16?

faqs.answer: The 'exaltation' of God's right hand signifies the supreme authority and unparalleled power of God. It means His power is not only immense but also recognized and honored above all other powers, both earthly and spiritual.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean for God's right hand to be 'exalted'?

faqs.answer: The verse finds resonance in the New Testament, particularly with Jesus sitting at the right hand of God. This position signifies Jesus' authority and participation in God's power, fulfilling the promise of divine intervention and valiant deeds.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the New Testament?

faqs.answer: The repetition of "the right hand of the LORD" emphasizes the importance and certainty of God's power and action. It reinforces the message that God's strength is not just a concept but a reliable force for good.
faqs.question: Q4: What is the significance of repetition in this verse?

faqs.answer: To 'do valiantly' in your life practically means to use your gifts and abilities to act with courage, integrity, and compassion. It means standing up for what is right, helping those in need, and persevering through difficulties with faith in God.
